Authors:
Wassila Aigoun, Georgina Elena, Ana Cabral, Maela Leon,
Nasserdine Sabaou, Josep Armengol, Cherifa Chaouia, Alla Eddine
Mahamedi, Akila Berraf-Tebbal
Title:
Characterization and pathogenicity of Cylindrocarpon-like
asexual morphs associated with black foot disease in Algerian grapevine
nurseries, with the description of Pleiocarpon algeriense sp. nov.
Keywords:
black foot, Dactylonectria, Pleiocarpon, taxonomy,
phylogeny, Vitis vinifera
Abstract:
During a survey of black foot disease in Algerian
grapevine nurseries, a collection of 79 Cylindrocarpon-like isolates
were obtained. Based on morphology and DNA sequence data of histone H3
(his3), three species of Dactylonectria were identified including
Dactylonectria torresensis (40 isolates), D. macrodidyma (24 isolates)
and D. novozelandica (14 isolates). In addition, one isolate belonging
to the genus Pleiocarpon was found and it is described here as a new
species, Pleiocarpon algeriense, based on morphological features and DNA
sequence data of the internal transcribed spacer region (ITS),
translation elongation factor 1-alpha (tef1), Î²-tubulin (tub2), and
large subunit nrDNA (LSU). This is the first time that these species are
reported in Algeria. Pathogenicity tests, were conducted with
representative isolates from each species. All of them were able to
induce typical necrosis symptoms on grapevine cuttings. By comparing the
lesion length, Dactylonectria species were more aggressive than P.
algeriense.. These results emphasize the growing threat of black foot
pathogens, on most grapevine production areas in Algeria.
